articles.headline: A ‘Beat Trump’ Fervor Is Producing Big Turnouts for 2020 Democrats
articles.snippet: Almost a year before voting starts, candidates are drawing large, enthusiastic crowds on the campaign trail as voters hoping to oust President Trump assess the field.
articles.abstract: Almost a year before voting starts, candidates are drawing large, enthusiastic crowds on the campaign trail as voters hoping to oust President Trump assess the field.
articles.lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY — They dragged their friends to see Bernie Sanders in Iowa. In South Carolina, their unrelenting selfie requests made Cory Booker late. And in New Hampshire, so many showed up at a church for an event with Kamala Harris that an overflow crowd had to stand outside in the snow.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember

articles.headline: How Equifax Complicates a Simple Task: Freezing a Child’s Credit
articles.snippet: A number of Your Money readers took Ron Lieber’s advice to freeze their children’s credit. Equifax’s process didn’t always work. Please keep trying.
articles.abstract: A number of Your Money readers took Ron Lieber’s advice to freeze their children’s credit. Equifax’s process didn’t always work. Please keep trying.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the new Equifax chief executive, Mark Begor, appeared before the House Financial Services Committee last week, he put on a brave face and offered conciliatory words.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Manafort’s 47 Months: A Sentence That Drew Gasps From Around the Country
articles.snippet: Judge T.S. Ellis III called sentencing guidelines that recommended 19 to 24 years for Paul Manafort “way out of whack,” the same way critics described the punishment Judge Ellis handed out.
articles.abstract: Judge T.S. Ellis III called sentencing guidelines that recommended 19 to 24 years for Paul Manafort “way out of whack,” the same way critics described the punishment Judge Ellis handed out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge T.S. Ellis III offered some pointed advice for those who expected him to throw the book at President Trump’s former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, for perpetrating a decade-long, multimillion-dollar fraud scheme.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: The Bull Market Began 10 Years Ago. Why Aren’t More People Celebrating?
articles.snippet: Americans are still scarred by the financial crisis, and the fruits of this decade’s record-breaking rally fell mostly to the rich.
articles.abstract: Americans are still scarred by the financial crisis, and the fruits of this decade’s record-breaking rally fell mostly to the rich.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial system had nearly collapsed. The deepest recession in decades was devouring over 700,000 jobs a month. Roughly $13 trillion in stock market wealth, slowly rebuilt since the dot-com bust, had again been incinerated.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, Plans for a Monument to Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: A group in San Jose, Calif., wants a worldwide competition to design a suitable landmark to celebrate the achievements of the tech companies.
articles.abstract: A group in San Jose, Calif., wants a worldwide competition to design a suitable landmark to celebrate the achievements of the tech companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Paris has the Eiffel Tower. St. Louis is inseparable from the Gateway Arch. Seattle boasts the Space Needle. Washington has its Monument.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld

articles.headline: In South Africa’s Fabled Wine Country, White and Black Battle Over Land
articles.snippet: A generation after apartheid, the Stellenbosch region is gripped by a struggle that pits white citizens who still control much of the economy against their black neighbors.
articles.abstract: A generation after apartheid, the Stellenbosch region is gripped by a struggle that pits white citizens who still control much of the economy against their black neighbors.
articles.lead_paragraph: STELLENBOSCH, South Africa — One cold morning, Stefan Smit, a white farmer in South Africa’s stunning wine region, woke up to find his vineyard under siege.
articles.byline: By Selam Gebrekidan and Norimitsu Onishi

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders-Style Politics Are Defining 2020 Race, Unnerving Moderates
articles.snippet: The leading Democratic candidates have largely broken with consensus-driven politics and embraced progressive ideas on health care, taxes, the environment and Middle East policy.
articles.abstract: The leading Democratic candidates have largely broken with consensus-driven politics and embraced progressive ideas on health care, taxes, the environment and Middle East policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Sign up for our politics newsletter and join our conversation about the 2020 presidential race.]
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: U.S. Continues to Separate Migrant Families Despite Rollback of Policy
articles.snippet: President Trump officially rescinded the practice of separating migrant families at the border, yet more than 240 children have been separated since.
articles.abstract: President Trump officially rescinded the practice of separating migrant families at the border, yet more than 240 children have been separated since.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Nearly nine months after the Trump administration officially rescinded its policy of separating migrant families who have illegally crossed the border, more than 200 migrant children have been taken from parents and other relatives and placed in institutional care, with some spending months in shelters and foster homes thousands of miles away from their parents.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Caitlin Dickerson

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Says Its Culture Has Changed. Some Employees Disagree.
articles.snippet: Regulators have said the bank cannot grow until it fixes practices that led to a series of sales scandals. Employees report limited progress.
articles.abstract: Regulators have said the bank cannot grow until it fixes practices that led to a series of sales scandals. Employees report limited progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo has spent years publicly apologizing for deceiving customers with fake bank accounts, unwarranted fees and unwanted products. Its top executives say that because they have eliminated the aggressive sales targets that spurred bad behavior, the bank’s culture has changed.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: How ISIS Is Rising in the Philippines as It Dwindles in the Middle East
articles.snippet: In the lawless jungles and seas of the southern Philippines, militants launch deadly attacks under the black flag of the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: In the lawless jungles and seas of the southern Philippines, militants launch deadly attacks under the black flag of the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: BASILAN, the Philippines — Across the islands of the southern Philippines, the black flag of the Islamic State is flying over what the group considers its East Asia province.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech and Jason Gutierrez

articles.headline: Footage Contradicts U.S. Claim That Nicolás Maduro Burned Aid Convoy
articles.snippet: A reconstruction of the moment when a truck bearing humanitarian supplies was set on fire shows the likely cause was a Molotov cocktail thrown by a protester.
articles.abstract: A reconstruction of the moment when a truck bearing humanitarian supplies was set on fire shows the likely cause was a Molotov cocktail thrown by a protester.
articles.lead_paragraph: CÚCUTA, Colombia — The narrative seemed to fit Venezuela’s authoritarian rule: Security forces, on the order of President Nicolás Maduro, had torched a convoy of humanitarian aid as millions in his country were suffering from illness and hunger.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey, Christoph Koettl and Deborah Acosta

articles.headline: Defying Congress, Trump Plans to Renew Fight for Border Wall Funding
articles.snippet: The president’s budget, to be unveiled Monday, asks for $8.6 billion to build border barriers while increasing military spending and cutting domestic programs.
articles.abstract: The president’s budget, to be unveiled Monday, asks for $8.6 billion to build border barriers while increasing military spending and cutting domestic programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Trump, undaunted by perhaps the most bruising legislative defeat of his tenure, plans to kick off a fresh effort on Monday to pressure Congress to pay for a wall along the southwestern border, most likely setting up another showdown with Democrats who have vowed to block his signature project.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: India Fights Diabetic Blindness With Help From A.I.
articles.snippet: A partnership with Google is part of a global effort to build and deploy systems that can detect signs of illness and disease in medical scans.
articles.abstract: A partnership with Google is part of a global effort to build and deploy systems that can detect signs of illness and disease in medical scans.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADURAI, India — The Aravind Eye Hospital will treat anyone who comes through the door, with or without money.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz

articles.headline: Trump Administration Steps Up Air War in Somalia
articles.snippet: Even as the Trump administration pulls back from counterinsurgency operations elsewhere, airstrikes targeting Islamist militants in Somalia have soared.
articles.abstract: Even as the Trump administration pulls back from counterinsurgency operations elsewhere, airstrikes targeting Islamist militants in Somalia have soared.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American military has escalated a battle against the Shabab, an extremist group affiliated with Al Qaeda, in Somalia even as President Trump seeks to scale back operations against similar Islamist insurgencies elsewhere in the world, from Syria and Afghanistan to West Africa.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Netanyahu-Trump Partnership Is Stronger Than Ever. Are These Its Final Days?
articles.snippet: The relationship has no precedent in their countries’ history, with deep parallels in their politics and struggles with scandal. But as an Israeli election approaches, is this the last hurrah?
articles.abstract: The relationship has no precedent in their countries’ history, with deep parallels in their politics and struggles with scandal. But as an Israeli election approaches, is this the last hurrah?
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In his increasingly uphill re-election battle, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s secret weapon is no secret.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: Boeing Faces Questions About Its New 737 Max Jets After Ethiopia Crash
articles.snippet: For the company, scrutiny of the jet goes to the heart of its business — the 737 Max has been its best-selling plane ever.
articles.abstract: For the company, scrutiny of the jet goes to the heart of its business — the 737 Max has been its best-selling plane ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trouble appeared to begin almost immediately after takeoff. The pilots told air traffic controllers that they were having technical problems. And the plane seemed to repeatedly climb and dive before a final plunge.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Zach Wichter

articles.headline: How the Internet Travels Across Oceans
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of miles of cable connect continents to support our insatiable demand for communication and entertainment. Companies have typically pooled their resources. Now Google is going its own way.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of miles of cable connect continents to support our insatiable demand for communication and entertainment. Companies have typically pooled their resources. Now Google is going its own way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of miles of cable connect continents to support our insatiable demand for communication and entertainment. Companies have typically pooled their resources. Now Google is going its own way.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano, Karl Russell, Troy Griggs, Blacki Migliozzi and Chang W. Lee

articles.headline: Egypt Looks to Offshore Gas Field for Growth and Influence
articles.snippet: A natural gas discovery could bolster the economy and revive the country’s regional clout. But Egyptians battling unemployment and inflation might gain little.
articles.abstract: A natural gas discovery could bolster the economy and revive the country’s regional clout. But Egyptians battling unemployment and inflation might gain little.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi likes to flaunt his plans for modernizing Egypt, like the flashy new administrative capital rising from the desert outside Cairo. But most Egyptians view his rule as a time of painful belt-tightening, with soaring inflation, a currency crash and cuts to subsidies that have made fuel, electricity and water more expensive.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Beto O’Rourke Moving Toward a 2020 Race He Could Upend, Ready or Not
articles.snippet: The former Texas representative has not toured Iowa or New Hampshire or assembled a campaign infrastructure. But he appears to lack an obvious big-ticket policy idea.
articles.abstract: The former Texas representative has not toured Iowa or New Hampshire or assembled a campaign infrastructure. But he appears to lack an obvious big-ticket policy idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beto O’Rourke has driven alone across the plains, straining to find his emotional bearings — or at least a Pancake House in Liberal, Kan. He has collected an “El Pasoan of the Year” award, before a modest audience, and smiled coyly through an interview with Oprah Winfrey, before a bigger one.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Tesla Says Never Mind: It Raises Prices and Keeps Most Stores
articles.snippet: Elon Musk’s company is reversing course after saying it would close stores to cut costs. It announced a 3 percent price increase on most models.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk’s company is reversing course after saying it would close stores to cut costs. It announced a 3 percent price increase on most models.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just days after saying that it would close most of its stores, Tesla is making an abrupt U-turn.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Trump Proposes a Record $4.75 Trillion Budget
articles.snippet: The president’s budget request for the 2020 fiscal year has little chance of becoming law because Congress controls spending, and Democrats control the House.
articles.abstract: The president’s budget request for the 2020 fiscal year has little chance of becoming law because Congress controls spending, and Democrats control the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump sent Congress on Monday a record $4.75 trillion budget plan that calls for increased military spending and sharp cuts to domestic programs like education and environmental protection for the 2020 fiscal year.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Michael Tackett
